close_symbols: struct MHD_Connection

enum MHD_CONNECTION_* (MHD_CONNECTION_INIT, _REQ_LINE_RECEIVING, _REQ_LINE_RECEIVED, _REQ_HEADERS_RECEIVING, _HEADERS_RECEIVED, _HEADERS_PROCESSED, _CONTINUE_SENDING, _BODY_RECEIVING, _BODY_RECEIVED, _FOOTERS_RECEIVING, _FOOTERS_RECEIVED, _FULL_REQ_RECEIVED, _START_REPLY, _HEADERS_SENDING, _HEADERS_SENT, _NORMAL_BODY_READY, _NORMAL_BODY_UNREADY, _CHUNKED_BODY_READY, _CHUNKED_BODY_UNREADY, _CHUNKED_BODY_SENT, _FOOTERS_SENDING, _FULL_REPLY_SENT, _CLOSED, _UPGRADE, …)
struct MHD_Response
connection->rp and connection->rq layout/fields (rp.response, rp.props.send_reply_body, rp.props.chunked, rp.rsp_write_position, rp.resp_sender, rp.resp_iov; rq.url)
response fields used (response->data, data_size, data_start, total_size, crc, mutex, data_iov)
MHD_send_data_ (semantics: return values, side effects on socket and buffer offsets)
MHD_send_hdr_and_body_ (semantics: return values, side effects on connection->rp.rsp_write_position and write buffer offsets)
MHD_send_sendfile_ (semantics: return values/side effects)
MHD_send_iovec_ (semantics: return values/side effects)
MHD_ERR_AGAIN_ (error code tested to decide early return vs close)
HTTP_100_CONTINUE and MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (data and length used in CONTINUE_SENDING case)
CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR macro (definition/expansion) and MHD_connection_close_ (what it does to connection->state and lifetime)
check_write_done (what state transitions it performs on connection->state)
try_ready_normal_body (return values like MHD_NO, side effects e.g. unlocking mutex, possible connection close/state changes)
MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ and MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (used around response->crc to protect critical sections)
MHD_PANIC (behavior when triggered)
mhd_assert macro (expansion/configuration: does it abort, call __builtin_unreachable, or compile out?)
__builtin_unreachable (semantics for compiler/static analysis — used as indicator of impossible paths)

preprocessor flags that change control flow/compiled code: HTTPS_SUPPORT, DEBUG_STATES, HAVE_MESSAGES, _MHD_DEBUG_SEND_DATA, _MHD_HAVE_SENDFILE, UPGRADE_SUPPORT, MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS / MHD_USE_W32_THREADS
MHD_run_tls_handshake_ (used when TLS is present — can cause early return or change tls_state)
MHD_resp_sender_sendfile constant (to detect sendfile code path)
SIZE_MAX and uint64_t overflow check (used to decide if branch calls MHD_PANIC)
MHD_update_last_activity_ (side effects — even if not changing state, understand if it can call __builtin_unreachable or change liveness)
explanation: To determine whether any case labels or code paths in MHD_connection_handle_write are truly unreachable you must know: the concrete layout and possible runtime values of connection->state and related fields (so include struct MHD_Connection, the enum/defines for all MHD_CONNECTION_* states, and the rp/rq/response fields referenced). Many decisions in the function depend on called routines' return values and side effects (MHD_send_data_, MHD_send_hdr_and_body_, MHD_send_sendfile_, MHD_send_iovec_, try_ready_normal_body, MHD_run_tls_handshake_) and on specific error/sentinel constants (MHD_ERR_AGAIN_, MHD_resp_sender_sendfile, HTTP_100_CONTINUE, MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_, SIZE_MAX). Macros and compile-time flags (HTTPS_SUPPORT, DEBUG_STATES, HAVE_MESSAGES, _MHD_DEBUG_SEND_DATA, _MHD_HAVE_SENDFILE, UPGRADE_SUPPORT, thread-related flags) change which code is compiled and therefore affect reachability. The CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR macro and MHD_connection_close_ must be known because they may modify connection state or free the connection (making subsequent code unreachable). The function check_write_done and try_ready_normal_body can change connection->state (or unlock mutex / close the connection) and so are essential to reason if later case labels can be hit. Assertions, MHD_PANIC and __builtin_unreachable semantics affect whether branches are legitimately considered unreachable by static analysis or can abort at runtime. Finally, the mutex helpers (MHD_mutex_lock_chk_/unlock) and MHD_update_last_activity_ are included because they participate in code paths that may early-return or alter synchronization/state; their behavior matters for precise reachability reasoning.
